>>53016102
Agreed, it actually has quite a bad story.

It sets up questions about the morality of catching and battling Pokemon, then abandons it just to reveal that Ghetsis was just a typical villain who wanted power all along. It also sets up a mystery about who N is and where he came from and doesn't resolve it.

People think it has a good story just because it follows a more typical JRPG structure in which the characters actively move the story along.

Sun and Moon did it better by having the Lillie/Lusamine storyline actually resolve itself.

>What's this all about?
Showderp is a game where one of us declares himself the champ and takes a ragtag team of six Pokémon assembled by anons into an online competitive Pokémon battling simulator.
To quote one of Showdown's tranny mods...
>@MacChaeger: None of these people are youtubers
>@MacChaeger: They impersonate verlis to to gain notoriety and attract new members
>@MacChaeger: These people regularly trick others into getting locked
>@MacChaeger: this is the single most toxic group of players on PS

>How does it work?
After the current champ calls "new champ", the first anon to claim the title is our champ. He uses the first six legal Pokémon suggested after his claim as his team. Champ can also call "new team" when the old one became stale (rule of thumb: 40-60 minutes). Champ plays in National Dex unless specified otherwise.
Absolutely no experience is necessary and everything is done in-browser.

>Rules
1. Champ can't forfeit, intentionally throw a match, or timer stall.
2. Champ may not edit a set without the suggester's permission.
3. All Pokémon must be nicknamed. If the suggestion didn't have a name, champ makes one up.
4. Don't suggest twice, unless your last sugg was 15 minutes ago or champ explicitly asked for resuggs.
5. Champ should replace resuggs with fresh suggestions that come in later.
6. Don't spam the catalog with threads.

>Resources
Pokémon Showdown! BETA: https://play.dogars.org
Premade mons for National Dex: dogars.org
How to make a shitmon: https://pastebin.com/raw/ZAyX6kY2
OP copypasta: https://felswerfer.de/pastebin.php?id=3476cd150e10fda4cd72

To be honest, from a continuity perspective, the newest episode really triggers my autism.
>Ash and Pikachu are still walking after parting with Goh
>Oh wait, no they aren't, because he must've gone to Oak's lab to get Sceptile, Donphan, Noivern, and Buizel
>who were at the lab when Ash said he wasn't going to be back for a long while
>now it seems like Ash isn't in Kanto at all
>the variety of Pokemon that appeared in the forest suggests that Ash isn't in any region we know of, but a completely different land
>and Team Rocket is also there for some reason
>Latias is also there
With how specific and careful Journeys was about travelling to certain regions to see certain Pokemon, there's something a little... soulless about this new location that seems to have every single Pokemon in it. Next, Ash is going to bump into Misty in a similarly vague location, with four new Pokemon in his pocket, one of which was supposed to be in Alola.

I get that this won't bother everyone, but it just feels a bit lacking in specificity. These locations and assortments of Pokemon are giving these final episodes a sort of 'dream', or 'coma' like feeling, where the details keep getting switched around and nobody knows or says where exactly they are. The lack of narrator in episode 1 contributed to this weird feeling. Is none of this even actually happening?

>>53018583
>>53018636
Animator here, just graduated and entered the industry. I can tell you peripherally that I recognize Toon Boom there, which is what most studios in the west are using nowadays. I wasn't aware OLM used it, but I've heard rumblings that some Japanese studios have started to use it so who knows. It's extremely expensive to have a license and can be difficult to pirate, so there's a chance that's a real animator who took this image.
There's also timing sheets on the right in the same format that Japanese animators use (we use a different format in the west), so this is likely an actual Japanese person who isn't larping.
The Toon Boom file is only 105kb, could be legit if it's very WIP, for reference I just finished a scene that's about 8 seconds long that's 248kb and used rigs, not frame by frame.
There's also a template imported which could be OLM's personal template, that's not generated by default.
The tablet being used looks like a Wacom Cintiq Pro, which retails from $1,500-$3,500 depending on screen size. I doubt anyone except a professional artist would have such an expensive piece of equipment.
It does look like an office space as well since people don't tend to have old phones like that anymore.
This could also just be someone with access to these things larping as OLM staff with all the other shit being true.
As for this being a real 4chan post, I doubt it. The image is likely to be real in my opinion but the person who posted it here probably took it from someone's twitter or something.

This thread is for the growth of artists and those who draw for fun. If you're going to give critique, please do it constructively. Rude or blunt critiques won't help anybody.

Requesters are free to request what they wish, but avoid bumping your request every half hour as it's only going to put people off; try giving it a few hours or more.

Also, be mindful that requests are done at the discretion of the artists, not on a first come first serve basis.

Please remember to save any piece of art you like from these threads, as we may never know when the archive will start deleting images again. Artists can and are recommended to post their works on other outlets for archival purposes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52985048
>>52988537
The multiple abilities/innates is something with a lot of potential, but I just do not think the way Exceeded implemented it is good.
It's just egregiously awful that so many abilities have additional effects added to them. What the fuck? It's a system built around multiple abilities. If you want multiple effects, you should put them in different abilities to mix and match instead of trying to shove it into a single ability.
I hope the Voyager hack does multiple abilities better. Are there any other hacks implementing multiple abilities?
Anyways, some of my ideas for multiple ability systems:
>separate abilities into innate and learned
>innate abilities can't be changed, reinforcing the pokemon species' identity and playstyle
>learned abilities are either earned through level up from a specific pool in a manner similar to moves, or through special conditions in a manner similar to special evolutions
>learned abilities can be passed down through breeding, allowing for new synergies with abilities not normally learned
>don't allow for a free for all ability fest, as it weakens the reinforcement of a pokemon species' identity and playstyle, as well as enable lazy and broken combos.

>>52991401
If Tyranitar can have any 3 abilities from a pool of 10 that just makes guessing which ability combo your foe's using exponentially harder unless there is literally only one good option.

I love this Innate system. Unironically the best shit I've seen in any hack in decades. Though I do wish RNG was removed from the Innates. Also can "When this Pokemon makes contact with the enemy" and "When the enemy makes contact with this Pokemon" abilities trigger from either type of Contact? A Goodra hitting a foe should apply the Gooey speed loss just like when Goodra is being hit by a foe.

Reminds me of how Effect Monsters worked in Yugioh, back when you had to choose between a strong Normal Monster without an effect (in this case, a strong pokemon with a relatively boring ability/innate set) and an Effect Monster whose effect makes up for his lack of direct power (innates designed to make the pokemon interesting, maybe even strong). And because these Innates are designed for the Pokemon, things actually feel somewhat balanced. Sure, some effects used RNG like Barrel Dragon but that was rare.

I have never actually used a Rattata on my team before. Except when I was 9 and I'd catch shitmons to use as decoys sent out to die when item-healing my Vaporeon and Charizard and Kadabra. But this game makes me want to experiment with gimmicky underpowered shitmons that could finally help my team or serve a useful niche besides "Well SOMEBODY needs to use HMs" or "Guess somebody has to be my Flying type until I can catch the one I want".

I have no clue if there's a more reliable way but from what I've found, copypasting specific variations of autotiles seemingly requires you to do the manual box selection and copy paste the tiles to wherever you need them. unfortunately bringing them to separate layers will require you to copypaste from something that has said tile on the same layer
but if you're trying to copypaste stuff onto other maps you'll have to do an entire process because for some reason the program clears the clipboard when you move over to different maps
>open a separate project that isn't the one you're currently working with
>paste the selected tiles onto whatever map is open in the second project
>do NOT deselect
>move back to the main project window
>switch maps to whatever you're trying to paste things to
>move back to project #2, making sure whatever you pasted is still selected
>copy
>move back to main project
>paste

rmxp is otherwise decently intuitive so I have no clue how they shat the bed so hard in this specific aspect

posts.name: Anonymous

>>53020121
I tackled this issue, at least with regards to bugs, by moving then to midgame and buffing their stats. Since our games are hacks, it is important to be honest with yourself that anyone playing them has already played a lot of pokemon games, and therefore you'll want to shake things up some. The first warning sign of a hack, for me, is if the first 3 routes contain ALL early route mons (bugs, regional normal types regional bird) crammed into the same space in an 8+ pokemon encounter table
Dreadful.
Become comfortable with shifting Pokemon from places you're used to them being, and be prepared to adjust their stats a little accordingly.

hello /vp/. I see a lot of people seem to struggle to play gold and silver, asking about pokemon like houndour and getting the wrong impression of the game.
this is the ideal gold/silver playthrough
>pick any starter
>play game as normal
>catch bellsprout
>trade bellsprout for ROCKY the onix in violet city
>box starter
>beat Falkner with ROCKY
>(optional) obtain EGG
>play game as normal
>get KENYA the spearow (you have to deliver it eventually otherwise the run is soulless)
>catch drowzee
>trade drowzee for MUSCLE the female machop in goldenrod
>beat Whitney with MUSCLE the female machop
>your optional egg should be hatched now
>continue as normal
>get EEVEE the eevee from BILL the faggot
>beat Morty using MUSCLEs foresight, KENYAs pursuit, and/or by leveling EEVEE to get bite (optional: metronomes from the mystery egg pokemon)
>continue as normal
>catch krabby
>trade krabby for VOLTY the voltorb in olivine
>continue as normal
>evolve your EEVEE into VAPOREON in order to traverse water-based terrain effectively
>get SHUCKIE the shuckle in cianwood
>use SHUCKIE to stall out Chuck's gym 1HP at a time and use VOLTY for poliwrath which will beat SHUCKIE with its water type surf attack (optional: use KENYAs strong peck attack to deal with fighting type monster trainers)
>if you have 7 pokemon now because youre using optional pokemon or still have KENYA, you must now either deliver KENYA or return SHUCKIE
>if you choose to keep KENYA you should upgrade the strong peck attack into an even stronger fly maneuver now
>continue as normal
>defeat jasmine using your trusty partner MUSCLE (this one's easy)
>continue as normal
>defeat Pryce using your trusty partners (many of them will work)
>continue as normal
>defeat Clair using all the skills you've learned throughout your adventure, such as VOLTYs light screen, KENYAs mirror move against dragonbreath and you can teach VAPOREON the icy wind TM you got from Pryce
the rest is up to you now...but never step foot in kanto

>>53014304
It's also disingenuous to try and pin this entire 'problem' that you have solely on the split.
Scyther originally had no Bug or Flying moves whatsoever, being entirely reliant on Normal moves. Over time it got access to Wing Attack and Silver Wind to let it actually use its Stab options. This is a very clear trend that represents a change in design philosophy that is solely pre-split, and even if Gamefreak hadn't implemented the split, you would have still seen the same thing over time, with new moves being added giving more and more mons access to powerful attacks that sort of movepool variance you're talking about.

That's certainly something Gamefreak could have avoided, but they could have avoided it while also implementing the split. If they didn't want a mon to have access to broader coverage or powerful STAB options, they can simply leave those moves out of its movepool.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>53005291
An "autocatcher" is a device that will throw normal pokeballs at everything in range until they flee or get caught, and also spin any pokestops that are in range. It's a hands free tool so that you can continue to accumulate resources while doing things that would normally prevent you from playing. I use mine all the time while driving, working, eating at restaurants, watching movies in a theater, etc. It doesn't do well against things with low catch rates, since it only uses red balls and can't do nice/great/excellent throws, but I wasn't going to catch pokemon while doing those things anyway, so I'm getting 50% of the pokemon around me instead of 0%. It also bypasses the speed check on pokestops, so I can spin stops while driving at freeway speeds. I got the Duomon so that my passenger can also use it, but also because the ones that you're supposed to get require you to constantly click a button in order to tell it to catch things. It's retarded, since the entire point of the Pokémon Go Plus software is to be hands free.

Those Special Auctions are triggered from having the Pokemon in your boxes/party. Plus I'm fairly sure that the Plates will be unique, each time an auction rolls it will be a different one until you have the full set.

>>53016078
Did you perhaps have ticked on the option: Check clock with the internet or some shit like that?

If yes, then it is most likely that. When your Switch checks if your clock has the correct time, if it is not synchronized to the internet's exact time, it will try to correct it and I'm sure that is interpreted as if you manually moved your clock which as you know rerolls raids.

tl;dr: tick off the check clock with internet option and the problem should go away. Source: it happened to me and now it has solved by doing that

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53019210
Depends on what you want out of it.

It IS a competitive fighting game, despite the superficially arena fighter-esque elements: The game still has unique movelists per characters, cancels, just-frames, an attack height system, etc, and the replay value still comes from playing against other people and improving rather then having a ton of modes or single player content. It is much more Street Fighter and less Naruto Ultimate Ninja Storm/DBZ budokai.

That said, for a competitive fighting game, it's approachable: There's no motion inputs, everything is either a button, a button plus a direction, two buttons, or holding and releasing a button, so at a low/starting level it's easier to pick up. The way the game handles attack heights and the whole 2d-3d shift mechanic also gives players more breathing room: The phase shift mechanic means you'll never be stuck in the corner the entire match because shifts will break you out of the 2d phase and back into the 3d phase where you're on more neutral ground, and heights exist not as a way to bypass and punish blocking, but to bypass and punish other moves during their active frames, meaning as a newbie you're not worrying about blocking high or low, rather height is a tool for YOU to use when you're on the defensive to get a reversal and hit through one of your enemy's moves.

Note this does not mean that there's less depth at a higher level of play: Some combos, tech, etc top players will be using take a lot of precise timing and dexterity (Garchomp's charge input run stance cancels are as such a lot of chomp players have to change their button layout) , and the whole phase shift mechanic is actually a huge source of an adapational and resource mangement skillgap at top play where players intentionally alter their combo composition and move choices on the fly to cause or delay shifts based on what's to their advantage; and there's still height mixups even if there's not height based blocking

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53019273
>>53019210
cont:

> and there's still height mixups even if there's not height based blocking

For example, if you have a move that bypasses and punishes move of X height, and the other player knows you have that, then they can try to use a different combo starter or meaty/on wakeup move or combo ender to try to punish you trying to punish that height

Basically, while it's said so often it's a cliche, Pokken really is "Easy to learn, hard to master": The changes Pokken makes to the fighting game template targets the sort of stuff new players tend to struggle with (motion inputs, being kept in the corner, dealing with what height to block), but those changes don't actually erase the skillgap at high level play and actually add more depth when it comes to neutral (when both players are trying to get a hit in and outwit the other player), having to adapt rather then flowchart, etc: The fact shifts break you back to a neutral state and the height system enables reversals really means there's a lot more back-and-forth where both players are in the driver's seat of the match.

But like any fighting game, you'll get out what you put in: The fun comes from learning, improving, and playing matches, not from unlocks or modes.

>>53019284
Firstly, I think worrying about "is X a good character to start with" is sort of a bad approach to getting into a fighting game: If there's a character or a game you like, start playing. If you worry about getting all the resources (not that frame data, combo guides, common punishes, etc aren't good to know) or starting with an easy character, you can easily pysche yourself out and put off just playing and learning the game/character you actually wanna play.

That being said, he actually is I think one of the easiest characters to start with. He has relatively short combos and just needs like a few stray grabs or short combos or single hits to do big damage. The drawback is he can struggle to get in to land those hits.

posts.com:
>>53019485
The phase shift system is entirely predictable/under the player's control, the tutorial just doesn't explain it.

3d > 2d shifts happen on basically any heavy hit or with most specials. Some lights cause it too. Basically, anything other then light projectiles will shift from 3d to 2d. This is why the game is more a 2d fighter then a 3d one: The 3d phase is basically just an additional buffer layer of neutral play.

2d > 3d shifts occur when the PSP guage is filled, and different moves, on hit, will add more or less points to that guage. Combos that hit 21 hits long also always auto-shift (as an anti-infinite mechanic), as does the universal grab (but not command grabs). However, the guage isn't in the UI, it's something you have to learn and memorize if you wanna keep track of it.

At high level play, players will alter their combos as the match goes on to always end on shifts to do optimum damage vs the shift interrupting the combo. Or they may intentionally go for combos or moves that maybe do less damage or aren't as safe, but that add less PSP, so shifts DON'T happen (thereby keeping the other player in the corner and under pressure, and maybe to get the chance to land an additional combo for more damage in that phase in the long term) or for combos that maybe don't do as much damage but do EXTRA PSP to shift faster, in case they wanna get out of pressure themselves or get the meter/health regen causing a shift gives you. Some moves also reduce or reset the PSP guage.

But like when you're starting out, I wouldn't worry about it that much: Just remember universal grabs always auto shift, heavy hits in the 3d phase shift to 2d, and the more hits you land in 2d the faster you shift to 3d. As it applies to machamp, you should also remember your command grabs do NOT add PSP, so you can use then in the 2d phase as much as you want, and wake up slap REDUCES the guage, allowing you to keep the enemy in the 2d phase longer.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53019666
>allowing you to keep the enemy in the 2d phase longer.

Just in case it's not obvious, the reason you want this is because Machamp is a lot better in the 2d phasr then the 3d phase.

Machamp is slow, and is his 3d phase projectiles suck. It's very difficult for machamp to win the field phase and cause the 3d > 2d shift, and he can't do much damage while in the 3d phase.

But even stray hits or single grabs in the 2d phase by machamp do insane damage. It's still hard to actually approach the enemy though, so once machamp IS up close in the 2d phase or especially when you've got the other character in the corner, it's in your interest to keep them there and to continue to land command grabs and rack damage up without causing a shift, most of the time, because it's hard to get back to that position.

In practice, tho, there are obviously situations where you may wanna giove up your advantagious position to land a combo rather then a command grab even if it shifts and allows the enemy to escape: Maybe you aren't comfortable yourself at the moment and just wanna take the damage you can get, maybe you'd really benefit from the extra meter causing a shift brings, etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53019666
>>53019685
Also also, to be clear, the PSP guage works indepedently for both players.

If you land like 4 hits and almost max out the PSP guage, the enemy landing a hit won't shift: each person has their own guage.

And again, there is no actual visible guage you can look at, sadly: You either need to remember the PSP value of each move, or just reemerge "if I use X move Y times, it will shift" or "If I use Z combo and then land Y move, that will be enough to shift" etc

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53020337
grass, fire, water, electric, psychic, dark, ice, and dragon are "special" types
move of those types do damage using your special as the attack stat and the opponents special as the defense stat.
after gen 1 they separated it into special attack and special defense so it's more like attack and defense.
the other types do physical damage which uses your attack stat and the opponents defense stat to calculate damage.
in gen 4 they separated it even more so now the move itself is what determines if you do special or physical damage but that'll make more sense when you get there (it's represented by a symbol on every move in that game so it's easy to understand)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53020359
Makes sense, ty

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The special stat is the stat used for the damage calculation of a move. From gen 1 to 3, it's used by moves of the special types (grass, fire, water, dark, electric, ice, psychic). From gen 4 onwards, it depended on the move itself regardless of typing.

In gen 1, the damage calculation for special attacks used the same stat both offensively and defensively. So whether you sent or recieved an attack, the special stat accounted for both cases, unlike physical types where the attack stat accounted for sent offensive damage and the defense stat for recieved defensive damage. In gen 2, the special stat was split into two to be exactly like physical type moves. So now sent offensive damage and recieved defensive damage were accounted by two seperate stats.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53019433
Hard to say. The need for 2 versions becomes lesser and lesser as they make random global faceless trading easier and easier. Its sort of judt a relic from the past, when the kids olaying it were guaranteed to have the game in handheod mode, and very likely to be out and about with it trading with and battling friends. Now you press a button and get box legendaries. Its a relic for sure but I'd also be kind of sad to see it go when it feels like the series is getting further and further away from its roots (starting, for fhe record, with XY). They will probably keep doing it though. I know a lot of retards who bought both despite there being less reason to do so than ever before.

>>53019447
Not really, the original intent was that you got social and linked up with your friends.
You were still only meant to buy red OR blue.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53019433
How is that even a question

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53019447
if anything it's the opposite. Originally they had no idea it was going to take off and it was probably more annoying in the 90s to produce it this way. There's a reason Tajiri didn't get to make it the way he originally wanted where the game technically had 30+thousand variations. It was literally just a fun gimmick that was supposed to inspire socialization which it did and is a good thing.

Now it's probably more greed related but I think PLA showed they understand at least somewhat how to make a single player experience and are willing to attempt it. So it's probably both greed and tradition.

>>53011306
Do you want people constantly coming over and touching you, violating YOUR personal space or time by yourself? No matter how much you love those people, of course not. Any time I talk with people about this, it seems like there's this expectation that the cat should be like a dog and almost be completely subservient to your will. But cats haven't been domesticated for nearly as long as dogs, they have a lot more personality than dogs do.

And that's ignoring the fact that cats DO want attention other than when they get in your face and demand it. Have you ever pet a cat only for it to take a single step away but still kinda stand there? The cat wants to to follow it and keep petting it. They like when you go out of your way to love them and pet them, it makes them feel special, important.

This is a two way street Anon, pets aren't toys. Yes, you get to decide when you want to interact with your pet, but your pet gets to decide when it wants to interact with you too.

>>53009149
Nah, they're absolutely cats, but the only living example of the Acinonyx genus. Their closest living relatives are the Puma genus (another single-family genus) and lack a floating Hyoid bone found in other big cats (what allows them to roar,) so as a result they make chirping or purring noises. And while their claws don't retract, that's as a result of their adaptations for hunting (built to run and chase down prey, so claws stay out to help provide more traction) and not because of dog genes in the pool.
Childhood is thinking tigers are class, adulthood is realising a pet cheetah would be far cooler.

>>53000951
You have to analize it from both sides

>Grim Darkwood
He is edge incarnated, his team can set up field effects, and many of their moves are game breakers, but looks like his main carrier is Tyranitar, so the rest is just fodder (so to speak).
Now, let's analyze Tyranitar: 31 IVs, 252 in all stats. But this is only in his first form. If Grim enters Berserk state, I imagine this can give him like a 100 BST bonus to Tyranitar, in his second form. Now the third one is the "funny one", since is Grim fused with his pokemon. This probably gives it a 200/300 BST boost, and the 3 only weakness rule is good, but it also makes him a glass cannon. If you have a team that has good move coverage, his final form can crumble just as easy. A Focus Sash - Endeavor - Quick Attack Rattata does the job because his tactic is "All in, all out". Grim's weakness is his own hubris, so you must hit there.

>Vox Xavion
Team is Smogon incarnated, probably they are 31 IVs, 252 EVs thanks to Dorado's drugs. But this isn't a bad thing per se.
While Grim shines in carrying on with his edge, Xavion is more of a tactician, and this makes his team more "situational". Let's not forget he also manipulated his team's DNA to make them "human". I imagine Landorus is more agile, and Lucario has a better fighting style. But speaking of Lucario, she is probably the weakest one. All Xavion does is use her as her spooge rag when miss schizo is busy/"controlling herself", so maybe her stats are weaker.
Defeat Lucario, and you have an opening. The second (and probably most dangerous) problem is Lustrorious. His typing is Fairy/Poison (if I remember correctly), but this typing changes in his second AND third form. And Xavion can fise with it, so I imagine it also has a BST boost. Lustrorious probably will have a powerful BST, considering it's a legendary (or a pseudo), so the fight will be a hard one.

It all depends in which situation we are: game logic or anime logic.

Cash caps at 9,999,999 though.

>>52986682
I'm thinking the Hisui Pokémon will be a situation like Alola and Galar region.
>Import Raichu to Alola
>Breed Pichu from the Raichu
>Pichu evolves into Pikachu, then Alolan Raichu

Scyther, Ursaring, Stantler, Rufflet, may lack the means to evolve into their Hisuian formes, though Scyther and Ursaring are item based.
Dartrix, Dewott, and Cyndaquil may only evolve into their original final stages.

Stuff that is Hisuian in their base form like Voltorb, Sneasel, Growlithe, Qwilfish, will probably breedable and able to evolve as normal.
Hisuian Basculin has the recoil damage requirement in evolution, but probably won't be an issue.

If Stantler is able to evolve into Wyrdeer, the Psyshield Bash requirement wouldn't be an issue if the move can be learned via breeding/mirror herb.
Primeape evolves by using Rage Fist 20 times, after all.

An update is likely able to add in the items and moves necessary for some of the evolution requirements, but the region requirement could potentially be "cheated" by Area Zero doing hax, or a special area in the speculated North-East DLC portion of the map.

Well dunno about a guide but basically
>research what outbreak you want
https://www.serebii.net/scarletviolet/massoutbreaks.shtml
>open map, check for it, if it's not there then go to system options, hover the day/hours/minutes and press ok

>Do this until you find the one you want
>Once you do that, go and auto battle until you get the message "there's not many of x pokemon left"
>Then save and start a picnic, make a sandwich for encounter 3, sparkling 3, title 3

https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/u/0/d/1Krmy76O7u4ZHG-QySfmNa-85UHwDnvJIldfOhr-cxRs/htmlview#

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52998913
Roaring Moon and Iron Valiant are the hardest to catch, with catch rate 10.

The others are more reasonable with 50 or 30.
Scream Tail, Brute Bonnet, Iron Bundle, Iron Hands, are catch rate 50.
Great Tusk, Flutter Mane, Slither Wing, Sandy Shocks, Iron Treads, Iron Moth, Iron Thorn, Iron Jugulis, are catch rate 30.

It's been a goal to catch all of them in beast balls, and I want to get them all shiny in beast balls eventually, so I've been developing strategies.

Flutter Mane can't be false swiped, unless you trick a Ring Target onto it. Level 56+ encounters don't have Wish.
Both Iron Hands and Iron Thorns risks recoil damage through Wild Charge, but a typical Spore Breloom with a ground tera type should do the trick. Level 55 and below don't have Wild Charge, and ground tera type also ignores sandstorm damage.
Brute Bonnet can't be spored, and Thrash can potentially lead to confusion self-KO. Paralyze it with Thunder Wave then switch to Ceruledge and False Swipe

That's about the extent of difficulty with them, none of the others carry self-KO risks.
Some of them can hit pretty hard, particularly Roaring Moon and Iron Valiant, but the Poison Heal + Spore Breloom at level 100 and activating Rock tera typing can survive most of it through toxic orb self-heal and persistent sporing.

>"Bear witness to the mighty Scream Tail, I've captured these Pokemon in Area Zero to take advantage of their TRUE power.."
>Nemona's expression softens. "O-Oh, for Pokemon Battles, right?"
>My fuzzy pink puffballs of destruction begin to close in on Nemona.
>"Oh not quite, dear rival." I whisper, "We're going to shoe you a true cacophony.. This is what happens when you break into my dorm.." I say as I I prepare my pink Sony Dolby Noise cancelling headphones

>"THIS IS WHAT HAPPENS TO TRESPASSERS LIKE YOU, NEMOMA!!"
>The roars of my mighty Scream Tail soften as Nemona's body goes limp. As mty little pink monsters reveal their psychic fangs, I leave them to rid of the evidence.
>"Enjoy the meal, my sweets." I say, leaving the dormitory to my Pokemon and my late rival's corpse.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53009642
Sadly it was doomed to being a shitmon. Rock is just too inaccurate offensively. Stone Edge only has 100 base power despite its atrocious accuracy. Rock Slide is more reliable, but not really worth it. Bombirdier is unironically better off using Brave Bird/Knock Off/Roost/Parting Shot instead of its signature ability. That's way more consistent and Dark/Flying is already decent, with its biggest drawback being that it has a hard time hitting certain Steel types (Steel/Fairy, Steel/Dark, and the less common Steel/Fighting). Rock doesn't help at all with that.

It's kinda like how Aurorus was destined to be a shitmon since there was no way a Sauropod Pokemon was ever going to be fast, and Ice/Rock is atrocious defensively. Bombirdier was designed to be a shitmon from the outset.

posts.name: Anonymous.

>>52994615
>Apparently weakness advantage
Doesn't matter if your team is strong and fast enough
>all my old sync pairs are worthless now since team building is now based on themes or something.
Team Building is based on buffing your most powerful DPS as fast as possible. This includes crits, terrains, zones. and weather, as well as debuffing your opponents' defenses including type rebuffs. Most units are "worthless" if compared to the most broken units that are out in the game, but since the majority of stages can be beaten without broken units barring certain EBs and the highest LG win streaks, "old" sync pairs can stull find their place from time to time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52994615
A weather/terrain/wish seems to be the latest meta trend that everyone does, but for starter, a buffs/debuffs are more important to stay your team alive so have sync pairs that can at least raise stats and crits. Also check Area Details for opponents because DeNa always plays own rules especially Extreme Battle Event.

>>53002577
Which type do you have less good pairs for, Rock or Ghost? That should really be helpful in deciding which one to get, as it's hard to say for sure without context. I'd probably advise for Korrina, since SS Diantha could cover your Rock needs.

Emmet can be a devastating Rock striker considering he maxes all his offensive stats by himself and has both single target and AOE moves. He does require sandstorm setup to max out his effectiveness though so you'll need setters like his bro, Anni or Lodge Raihan, or Bertha, hell Acerola would probably do. Also consider that both of his moves have below-average accuracy, and considering he's gauge heavy missing can hurt. He does gain Piercing Gaze with his grid but only at 3/5.

SS Korrina buffs all allies' crits and buffs herself quite nicely too, making her great for double DPS. Her ability to steal stats three times is highly valuable against buff-reliant opponents, especially since it helps her get her sync multiplier. She can hit deceptively hard even with her 2 gauge moves, since Spectral Thief activates damage multipliers for two of her passives at once. Most importantly she has exposed tummy She's not a necessity if you have good ghost pairs like Anni Lillie or SSR Cynthia, but it definitely doesn't hurt to have her.

posts.com:
Before Journeys unironically it's probably Brock, with his only competition being Misty and Clemont.

Cilan is also a gym leader but has worse feats and weaker pokemon.

Clemont showed a lot of strength against Ash during their gym battle even though he only barely trained beforehand, meaning he was around as strong as Ash for over half his gym challenge (and XY Ash was REALLY strong).

Misty's not as knowledgeable as Brock, but she still has a lot of battle experience.

Brock has the most battle experience overall, has travelled three full regions, is probably more knowledgable overall (about battles, medicine, and pokemon in general). His starter is also a Steelix that can mega evolve and tank fire-type Z-moves. He also branched out to train types other than his specialty (Ludicolo is basically the polar opposite to his specialty, he also has Chansey, Marshtomp and Forretress). So he's got the strongest pokemon, the most experience and knowledge, the best team diversity options and a mega evolution.

Until Iris got her offscreen level up Brock was definitely the strongest. Which fits since most feel he's also the best companion overall.

GSC is so much more bright and colorful

>>53016523
I understand what you mean about GSC using it's color pallette well but you're not being fair to RSE here.

RSE arguably has the most unique towns in the series:

Fortree
Pacifidlog
Sootopolis

Are all visually distinct and have specific themes that were barely possible on the Game Boy.

Rustboro, Dewford and Fallarbor manage to look unique too due to the larger range of tile sprites that the GBA made possible. Even Verdanturf has the longer grass tiles that makes it different from a place like Littleroot or Oldale.

If you want an example of a GBA game that looks bland and homogenised, take a look at FRLG instead.

Murkrow would probably be quite useful, though mainly because the other Dark type option is just Umbreon, or Sneasel in Crystal.
It's one thing to want to make the new pokemon rare so that they're more special, and in some cases like Tyranitar I think it works very well, but very few Gen 2 mons feel like they're powerful enough to really warrant how elusive they are.

gen 5 fixed HMs before cutting them because the only mandatory ones were strength and surf (cut at the start but they give you a pokemon with it right next to the tree and then you never have to use it again) and the strength boulders are set in place so you don't have to keep a pokemon with it just to go places you've already been (and most of those places are optional anyway) you literally never need an HM slave in BW. this was a direct response to HMs being the worst they've ever been in gen 4.

The problem comes in that most players are going to want to fill out their teams fairly early.
Especially in regions were there is a necessity to use multiple HMs.

Ideally most of your interesting monsters will have appeared before the 4-5th gym.
As most past that point will have to replace members of the player's team. In a game series that disincentivizes doing that by talking up the bonds between player and monster.

**No. 104 Karakara**
**Category**: Loneliness Pokemon
**Height**: 0.4m
**Weight**: 6.5g
**Type**: Ground
**Classification**: Grassland Pokemon
**Habitat**: (RGB) Pokemon Tower
(P) Pokemon Tower, Safari Zone
**Evolutions**: Garagara (Lv. 28)

>1996 Report:
>This Pokemon always wears a skull as a helmet upon its head. None have ever seen its face. But the reason it never removes its is because this skull once belonged to its deceased mother.
>On lonesome, moonlit nights, it will always cry in a loud, desolate voice. These cries echo within its skull and become a sad melody. Some say the name Karakara comes from the bone-rattling sound made whenever it cries, or whenever its head bumps around the skull. When it grows up, it will evolve into Garagara.
>While it is classified as a Grassland Pokemon, it is rarely ever found. Some have reported to have found it within the Safari Zone, but most as of late had been seen wandering the Pokemon Tower.

In all the discussion about Greninja so far there is one thing that I haven't seen mentioned.

Before these raids they run two special raids to give us a Pokemon to help us in the seven star. This pokemon never ends up being meta or ohko capable, at least not so far. But I do think it tells us something about the raid.

For example, before Charizard there was mimikyu and florges raids. This should have signaled to everyone that fairy was going to be viable and that Charizard would not have a steel attack

Similarly, before cinderrace, we got Gyarados and Gengar. Cinderrace did not end up having electro ball and ended up being more weak on the special side with how much it spammed bulk up.

The two pokemon being run before Greninja are.... Lucario and bronzing.
What does this tell us about Greninja?

posts.name: Anonymous

>>53019001
I'm not the best at explaining, but here we go

First thing is you can't see anyone else while in Area 0. However, they can see the pokemon you spawn and can fight them.

Basic rules, are we fly to area zero, all eat the correct level 3 shiny sandwich, and then go to right area to hunt for shinies. In our case, we'd go to the 4th research station. A lot of Iron Valiants spawn there, and you can look for shiny flutter mane around Lab Zero at the bottom.

Just keep in mind that any pokemon that you spawn only stay in your field of vision and not everyones. So say I see a Flutter Mane that you spawn, and you move far enough away that it despawns for you. It would despawn for me as well.

If one of us finds a shiny, just make a post alerting the other person. Because two people can catch the same shiny, the person who spawned it, and one other person in the union circle. All the person who spawned it has to do is save and then reload their save after the shiny is caught and it will reappear for them.


tl;dr
1. Picnic at Aera Zero and eat for right shiny type
2. Go to area where your target spawns
3. Find shiny
4. Alert partner you found shiny
5. Save before they fight it.
6. They catch shiny
7. You restart your game
8. You catch the shiny too.
9. ???
10. PROFIT!!!

>>52993796
Yeah admittedly in all my drafts and plans for writing with Latias, I always conceived of things being difficult and a bit sad for her after her brother died. Leading to issues that eventually need Ash to return to be solved (or something to that effect).
I'm going to use this excuse to ramble about my current writing

My current draft has Latias trying to fill the same role as her brother (quiet, distant protector, who remains overly careful in protecting not only the city but the secret of her existence). Of course, this approach doesn't work for her in the slightest. Latias is an outgoing, social animal, she can't handle the monotony of just patrolling the city, and most of all, she needs friends (which is even harder with Bianca out of Alto Mare so often nowadays for school). The obvious answer is that Latias needs to "move out". Nothing ever happens in Alto Mare that needs her, so it's not like her job of guardian is really holding her down. Yet, she's too scared of the possibility of something happening she can't even consider it. Bianca notices this of course, she knows Latias leaving would be best for her, but after losing Latios she can't handle the idea of losing Latias too. So she doesn't say anything.
That's the status quo until Ash comes back, just for a visit, and both Latias and Bianca realize the best path forward is a difficult one: Latias going on an adventure with Ash. To grow stronger, lose her fear of capture or harm, and finally grow into the person she's meant to be.

/vp/ tourist just passing through now that the Ashnime is finally ending, just wanted to say I'm unironically glad to see this thread and you degenerates are somehow still around and doing well and that I'm happy for you all.

I haven't been a hardcore Pokemon fan for the last 15 years or so, but I still remember finding the little dragon girl from the movie adorable and lavishing affection on her during postgame content in Emerald/Mystery Dungeon like it was yesterday.
Seeing you all still chugging on and staying loyal to your dragonwife for all this time and celebrating her reappearance just warms the heart. Perhaps it makes Gen 3 and its nostalgia not feel so long ago after all, or perhaps it just makes all those years seem like both a good time and a long time, if you all are still around.
And I'm always glad to see my fellow degenerates get their rare desert oasis of pandering to their niche ship or waifu in any series.

Thanks for reading my blog, and I hope you planefuckers win or at least get upgraded to main traveling partner/feMC levels by the end of Ash's last huzzah. Godspeed, you glorious motherfuckers.

>>52994428
Thanks a lot friend! Latias was my first ever crush when I was a kid. Having to manually catch her without the master ball I promptly used on some random legendary was quite the challenge. By this point she was easily my favorite mon and I still recall running around in Hoenn doing battles and entering her for the contests. Then some time later YouTube was created and I started finding M05 clips and I immediately fell in deep love with this cute shape-shifting dragon bird plane. Since then she has been living rent-free in my head as my one and only waifu and I have been using her in every pokémon game that I have owned. That same Latias now lives in Alpha Sapphire after traveling with me through all the games leading up to the the same region it all started.

It feels... weird. I am 27 years now and I have never been dissatisfied with how things turned out. I am fully self aware that all of this is fucking weird and I haven't really told anyone how I really feel besides two close friends of mine. I am neither socially nor physically weird and I work at a well-paying job. Literally nobody would suspect that over half of my live I have been in love with a fictional creature. I just don't want to let go of her as I genuinely love her. Sorry for the ramblings, I think I just wanted to get things off my chest to a community that might appreciate it. These threads have been great to find other like-minded people and I am happy to see I am not alone. I want to thank all of you for contributing!

>>52994663
Same case for me, except with a different Pokemon.
I'm 23, and work a blue collar trade. One of the "manly" ones. I'm not of the impression that I look, speak or act like a weirdo.
In fact, I make an active point of hiding my power level, feigning semi-ignorance when friends or workmates bring up most video game or internet things. To be fair, I'm not all that interested in them, I rarely game, and /vp/ is the only 4chan board I frequent. Make that social media site as a whole (Unless you count youtube).
You'd think I'm a true blue aussie cobber, mullet and all.
And yet, since watching M13, and that one zoroark episode of B/W, my mind has been broken by that rusefox.
It's sorta hard to explain, see. I must of been 11 at the time, maybe. I just saw her and something... clicked.
It isn't even purely horny, hell I'd argue it mostly isn't. I been doing that nofap thing for 6 months, and still dream of her, and falling asleep beneath that luxurious fur, or just something little like watching a movie together or enjoying a meal.
I'm not an imaginative fellow, but with her, I can vividly imagine the play of her fur in my fingers, her heartbeat against mine, y'know, that sorta thing.
I'm all too aware its weird.
Real bloody weird.
I'm sure Freud would have something or other to say about it (Funnily I've got a great relationship with both parents, so not that).
But there are bugger all nice sheilas in my town, so why not, eh?
Anyway, thats my rant for the month. Always nice knowing you aren't alone in being a bit of a loon.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I just beat Red in crystal and it was a fucking BATTLE.
I was grinding up my team of Feraligatr, Gengar, Slowking, Umbreon and Snorlax and was going to use an onix I got from Mt. Silver for his Pikachu.
I lost Snorlax while grinding the elite four at level 59! Disaster!
So I got pissed and decided to use my rare candies and just fight Red. Fuck it. Just fuck it.
Final team was:
Bepis the Feraligatr lv 62
Mr. Knox the Slowking lv 62
Tsushima the Gengar lv 64
Enoch the Umbreon lv 62
Gibraltar the Onix lv 48
a random electrode from rocket hideout that I sacked to Charizard during the fight.

Onix trolled pikachu to death in like 30 turns lol
I let it die to Espeon then Umbreon obviously came in and walled for days
He sends in Snorlax. I try to toxic/confuse ray troll it for a bit and he uses rest, it didn't work out so I went into Gengar.
Mean look then curse, two moves I'd had to keep on him since the very beginning and it finally paid off and I killed the fatass.
Red sends Venusaur to be 2HKO'd by my Gengar's psychic.
Then Charizard comes out.....with sun up already.
I sack Electrode, go into Feraligatr and unfortunately lose him to a crit flamethrower +fire spin chip, but gengar is able to come in and pick him off with thunder punch.
Finally, blastoise. I go for curse yet again (I had leftovers equipped so I got back to full on snorlax), and then go into Slowking to sit on him for a couple more turns.

Only Slowking and Gengar survived the end, but it was an epic battle.

On to the next. I'm thinking possibly Red/Fire Red or....something else. Give suggestions please! This was a really fun nuzlocke aside from a lot of grinding. Gengar was the MVP the whole run pretty much. 40 hours of playtime!

Franchise run with species clause so far
Despite almost losing my Crystal run, I thought GSC was pretty alright. If you have checks for Bugsy's Scyther, Whitney's Miltank and Morty's Gengar, most of the midgame will be on the easier side even with hardcore rules since Jasmine's lv 35 Steelix will let you overlevel and crush everything until Lance
Lance also having a lv 50 Dragonite means you might be over ten levels higher than most of the rest of the E4, so you really only have to prep for him

Overall, lots of fun so far, but I'm glad I'm getting into the games with more fun movesets to be used. I just hope I didn't use too many Kanto mons since I need those for FRLG and Let's Go

Hoppip is not bad though, he has speed and great utility moves and can absolutely troll anything in the game to death with sleep powder and leech seed. He is a chore to train, but I find him fun to use.
Just know if you use a grass type, its an uphill battle.

First game of gen 3 is done
I was a bit worried during midgame as my team wasn't feeling so hot, but an Abra in Granite Tunnel helped carry me into a better setup later on. Camerupt is way more solid than I thought, and Sceptile starts doing damage once Leaf Blade comes in

Every fight in E4 was a sweeping breeze. Glacia was funny as Glalie is such a shit mon that its pathetic Crunches didn't stop Alakazam from setting up and wrecking her team

I thought I could do the same to Drake as Shelgon is very weak, but Alakazam got two Speed reductions from Rock Tomb, and only survived vs the upcoming Flygon because it decided to Sand Attack instead of killing me, so I had to dance a bit, including a risky Masquerain switch in vs Salamence's Fly. He gladly survived and Ice Beam'd the dragon for the win

I decided to put my profane crab creation against Steven, thinking I could at least take down a few mons, so I strapped her with a Pecha Berry and started dancing on Skarmory, who missed a Toxic, set up Spikes and hit Toxic, then promptly got Brick Broken, letting Old Bay go berserk on Steven's team, distributing Returns and Brick Breaks without a shred of mercy

I hadn't played Gen 3 in ages, and it's better than I remember, but the whole "too much water" thing is a bit real during late game. Onwards onto Sapphire now

And Sapphire is done

This time I felt confident enough going into the E4 that I didn't even bother getting a 5th slot. I did have plenty of good mons that could go there (Makuhita, Ninjask/Shedinja, Exploud, Torkoal) but I thought I was strong enough with this setup and decided to save mons for the next leg of the challenge

Turns out I was right, as the only thing better than a setup sweeper is a setup sweeper with Hypnosis. The only E4 member I didn't sweep with Lunatone was Sidney, where I led with Blaziken, got one Bulk Up off before getting Roared away, letting Ludicolo blast stuff with his coverage

Of course, Hypnosis being a 70% move, it would eventually miss, and it did against Steven's Skarmory, three times in a row, actually. After Spikes, Toxic (Pecha'd) and Toxic again, Hypnosis finally hit, letting me finally set up. The poison damage quickly added up, leaving me with 20 HP against his Metagross. I decided to just sac with a Hypnosis, which missed, so I went into Slaking, put him to sleep with a Yawn, switched to Ludicolo and let him Surf Metagross until Steven's Full Restores were drained

I could have done this deathless but at this point, might as well take one hit considering how easy everything else was

I'm happy I still managed to save a lot of good mons for Emerald and the remakes, but for now it's time to return to Kanto for Fire Red

>>53017495
I completely agree the battle system itself is too slow in main series, especially in the 3d generations where the animations themselves aren't nearly as engaging as the battle sim games yet still manage to be just as long on average. The game wastes time delivering information and animations separately, right down to running the animation for multi-hit moves several times even in cases like pin missile where it would make more sense if the attack was performed once and only the number of projectiles hitting their mark varied. They could get away with running the same animation regardless of successful hits and just putting up text saying how many hit considering how little variation everything else has anyways. Even the battle sims have some of that but not nearly as egregious because they mostly run text and animations together so even the longer animations don't hold the game up as much. Only exception to this was PLA where there were a lot of additional little qol improvements. Things like pokemon gaining the ability to learn moves or evolve upon level-up without the game stopping you to deal with that right then and there, actions were mapped to buttons so you didn't have to scroll through menus to do everything, and the animations themselves were a lot snappier than other games with the added bonus of battles happening in the overworld with a ui over it so you could still walk around and control the camera for a better/unique angle on the action and pokemon moving/turning to target each other so it felt really polished.
